bibl.title: Letter from Hugh S. Cumming to Laura Armistead Carter, October 14, 1925

div1.p: Cumming has the impression that Henry Rose Carter told Reed about his extrinsic incubation theory and asks Laura Carter if her father's work influenced Reed. An autograph note by Laura Carter attests to the influence of her father's work on Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Hugh S. Cumming to Laura Armistead Carter, October 14, 1925
div1.opener:
Biographic
Ravenel
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
IN REPLYING
ADDRESS THE SURGEON GENERAL
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
HSC'
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
BUREAU OF
THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
WASHINGTON
October 14, 1925.
Miss Laura Carter,
The Westmoreland,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
I am inclosing a note from my meticulous friend
Ravenel. It is my impression that your Father had told
Reed about his “extrinsic period” either before he left
Washington or (I have a vague recollection that someone
told me the latter) he met your Father at breakfast
immediately upon his arrival in Havana and discussed the
matter with him then.

Ravenel's statements about Nott's, Finlay's and
Sternberg's attitude are correct as you know. The part
which I wish to ask you to help me to learn is this: did
Reed have your Father's work in mind and did it influence
him toward investigating the mosquito theory.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, H. S. Cumming
Surgeon General. XX yes- See “Preliminary Note” of
Reed Board.
also - for further data - consult
Dr. Wade H. Frost.
L. G. C.
